This tutorial is based on Tim Head‚Äôs

Thank you to Anna Krystalli and Oliver Strickson for their help developing the R and Julia content, respectively.

Binder can take a long time to load, but this doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean that your Binder will fail to launch.
You can always refresh the window if you see the ‚Äú... is taking longer to load, hang tight!‚Äù message.

which will build your environment using a
and should, ultimately, be faster to build and launch.

This might mean that you just pick one script from a bigger project, or bring a subset of your data.

because we‚Äôll be using the public binder instance.

Why does the repo have to be public?

cannot access private repositories as this would require a secret token.
The Binder team choose not to take on the responsibility of handling secret tokens as

is a public service and proof of technological concept.
If accessing private repositories is a feature you/your team need, we advise that you look into building your own

Type the URL of your repo into the ‚ÄúGitHub repo or URL‚Äù box.
It should look like this:

As you type, the webpage generates a link in the ‚ÄúCopy the URL below...‚Äù box
It should look like this:
Copy it, open a new browser tab and visit that URL
You will see a ‚Äúspinner‚Äù as Binder launches the repo
If everything ran smoothly, you‚Äôll see a JupyterLab interface.
What‚Äôs happening in the background? - Part 1
While you wait, BinderHub (the backend of Binder) is:
Building a Docker image based on your repo
Launching that Docker image in the cloud
Connecting you to it via your browser

This time, click on ‚ÄúBuild Logs‚Äù in the big, horizontal, grey bar.
This will let you watch the progress of your build.
It‚Äôs useful when your build fails or something you think
Sometimes Binder‚Äôs build logs prints things in red font, such as warnings that

is often out of date because it‚Äôs regularly updated!) or installation messages, especially if you‚Äôre using R.
These red messages don‚Äôt necessarily mean there‚Äôs a problem with your build and it will fail - it‚Äôs just an unfortunate font colour choice!
What‚Äôs happening in the background? - Part 2
This time, BinderHub will read the configuration file you added and install the specific version of the package you requested.
In the above example, we used two equals signs (

.
This tells Binder to install that
Another way to pin a version number is to use the greater than or equal to sign (

) to allow any version above a particular one to be installed.
This is useful when you have a lot of dependencies that may have dependencies on each other and allows Binder to find a configuration of your dependencies that do not conflict with one another whilst avoiding any earlier versions which may break or change your code.
Finally, you could not provide a version number at all (just the name of the library/package) and Binder will install the latest version of that package.
In the above example, we copied a hash into our

file which is related to the version of the package we‚Äôd like to install.
For a full dependency graph, we would also need to include a

file which would document dependencies of dependencies.
Between these two files, we are able to instantiate an exact replication of a Julia environment.

Of course we can imagine that, as the environment grows and the inter-dependencies become more complex, it would become very taxing to write these files by hand!
The truth is that you‚Äôd never do it manually, the built-in package manager
In the above example, we specified that we want to use R in our project by including a date in

.
The date tells Binder which CRAN snapshot to source R and packages from.
These snapshots are sourced from the

(RSPM).
In the above example, the RSPM snapshot dated
is used and the version of R and

available at that date and installed.
For the example workflow to work correctly, please ensure you do not supply a date earlier than this example date.
This provides some rudimentary package versioning for R users but is not as robust as pinning versions in a

in Python.
For more robust and specific version pinning in R, have a look at the

If you save this notebook, it

be saved to the GitHub repo.
Pushing changes back to the GitHub repo through the container is not possible with Binder.
Any changes you have made to files inside the Binder will be lost once you close the browser window.
Binder is all about sharing your work easily and there are two ways to do it:
, type in the URL of your repo and copy the Markdown or ReStructured Text snippet into your

file.
This snippet will render a badge that people can click, which looks like this:

The grey bar displaying a binder badge will unfold to reveal the snippets.
Click the clipboard icon next to the box marked with ‚Äúm‚Äù to automatically copy the Markdown snippet.
Click the badge to make sure it works!
Another kind of dependency for projects is

.
There are different ways to make data available in your Binder depending on the size of your data and your preferences for sharing it.

The simplest approach for small, public data files is to add them directly into your GitHub repository.
They are then directly encapsulated into the environment and versioned along with your code.
This is ideal for files up to
from a few 10s MB up to a few hundred MB
, you can add a file called
file is a shell script that is executed as part of the image construction and is only executed once when a new image is built, not every time the Binder is launched.

New images are only built when Binder sees a new commit, not every time you click the Binder link.
Therefore, the data is only downloaded once when the Docker image is built, not every time the Binder is launched.

It is not practical to place large files in your GitHub repo or include them directly in the image that Binder builds.
The best option for large files is to use a library specific to the data format to stream the data as you‚Äôre using it or to download it on demand as part of your code.
For security reasons, the outgoing traffic of your Binder is restricted to HTTP/S or GitHub connections only. You will not be able to use FTP sites to fetch data on
There is no way to access files which are not public from

.
You should consider all information in your Binder as public, meaning that:
there should be no passwords, tokens, keys and so on in your GitHub repo;
you should not type passwords into a Binder running on
you should not upload your private SSH key or API token to a running Binder.
In order to support access to private files, you would need to create a local deployment of
where you can decide the security trade-offs yourselves.

Building a BinderHub is not a simple task and is usually taken on by IT/RSE groups for reasons around managing maintenance, security and governance.
However, that is not to say that they are the
groups of people who should/could build a BinderHub.

These packages aren‚Äôt necessary to download the data but we will use them to read the CSV file and make a plot
Click the binder badge in your README to launch your Binder
Once the Binder has launched, you should see a new file has appeared that was not part of your repo when you clicked the badge.
Now visualise the data by creating a new notebook (selecting ‚ÄúPython 3‚Äù from the Notebook section) and run the following code in a cell.

%matplotlib inline

import pandas

data = pandas.read_csv("gapminder.csv", index_col="country")

years = data.columns.str.strip("gdpPercap_")  # Extract year from last 4 characters of each column name
data.columns = years.astype(int)              # Convert year values to integers, saving results back to dataframe

data.loc["Australia"].plot()

These packages aren‚Äôt necessary to download the data but we will use them to read the CSV file and make a plot
Click the binder badge in your README to launch your Binder
Once the Binder has launched, you should see a new file has appeared that was not part of your repo when you clicked the badge.
Now visualise the data by creating a new notebook (selecting ‚ÄúJulia‚Äù from the Notebook section) and run the following code in a cell.

using DataFrames
using CSV
using Plots

data = CSV.read("gapminder.csv", DataFrame)

# Extract the row corresponding to Australia
aus_gdp = data[data[:, :country] .== "Australia", :]
aus_gdp = Matrix(aus_gdp[:,2:end])[:]  # as vector

# Extract the years as Ints from the column names
years = [x[end-3:end] for x in names(data)[2:end]]
years = parse.(Int, years)

# Plot
plot(years, aus_gdp)

These packages aren‚Äôt necessary to download the data but we will use them to read the CSV file, process it and make a plot
Click the binder badge in your README to launch your Binder
Once the Binder has launched, you should see a new file has appeared that was not part of your repo when you clicked the badge.
Now visualise the data by creating a new notebook (selecting ‚ÄúR‚Äù from the Notebook section) and running the following code in a cell.

library(readr)
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)

data <- read_csv("gapminder.csv") %>%
    pivot_longer(-country,
                 names_to = "year",
                 values_to = "gdpPercap",
                 names_prefix = "gdpPercap_",
                 names_transform = list(year = as.integer))

data[data$country == "Australia", ] %>%
    ggplot(aes(x = year, y = gdpPercap)) +
    geom_line()

Throughout this tutorial, we have been using the JupyterLab interface.
This is the default interface for newly created Binder instances.
However, this is not the only interface available on

, the Classic Notebook view and RStudio are available too.
(An R environment needs to be installed for RStudio to be available.)

You can access the different interfaces in different ways.
The easiest way is to use the buttons in the JupyterLab Launcher, but you can provide URL parameters to directly open a specific interface (or file!) when the Binder instance launches.
We‚Äôll now cover three ways you can manipulate your Binder URL to navigate between interfaces.
Here is the structure of the URL inside a running Binder instance running JupyterLab:
.mybinder.org/user/<a composite of your username, your repo name and a hash>/lab
You can change the interface from JupyterLab to either the Classic Notebook or RStudio by changing the
